entry.title: Re: From GOS attachment to generate spool or pdf
entry.content:
The issue is conceptual rather than technical.

OTF_TO_PDF can only convert OTF data (output generated by SAPscript / SmartForms / SAP Spool).
A GOS attachment is not OTF, it is already a stored binary document (PDF, DOCX, XLS, JPG, etc.).

That is why you get the error “OTF command ‘//’ endpoint missing” — you are passing non‑OTF binary data to OTF_TO_PDF.

Important clarification

  • GOS attachments uploaded from presentation server are stored via ArchiveLink / Content Server

  • They are not spool requests

  • OTF_TO_PDF must not be used for generic attachments

What you should do instead

Case 1: Attachment is already a PDF

  • Retrieve it using:

    • ARCHIVOBJECT_GET_TABLE or

    • SO_DOCUMENT_READ_API1

  • Convert SOLIX → XSTRING

  • Directly:

    • Download it

    • Display it

    • Attach it to email
      ✅ No conversion required

Case 2: You need a Spool
You cannot create a spool from an arbitrary attachment unless:

  • The attachment was originally generated by SAP (SmartForm / SAPscript)

Spool creation is only possible from:

  • SmartForm

  • SAPscript

  • Adobe Form

  • ABAP list output

Case 3: Attachment is DOC / XLS / IMG
SAP does not provide any standard FM to convert these to PDF.
Options:

  • Use an external converter (OpenText, Adobe, PDFLib, etc.)

  • Or store/display the original file as-is

Summary

  • OTF_TO_PDF ❌ cannot be used for GOS attachments

  • GOS attachments ≠ Spool output

  • If already PDF → just retrieve and display/download

  • Conversion to PDF requires external tools unless SAP-generated output

Hope this clarifies the limitation and correct approach.

entry.title: Re: Invoice attachment to R/3 system
entry.content: This is correct as per standard SRM → ECC design. Attachments added in SRM invoices are not transferred via IDoc to the backend FI document. As a workaround, customers usually: • Store attachments in a shared ArchiveLink repository accessible by both systems, or • Reattach documents in ECC via GOS, or • Build a custom solution using ArchiveLink APIs / middleware to replicate attachments (not SAP standard). There is no standard SAP note enabling SRM invoice attachments to appear automatically in FB03.

entry.title: Re: Problem in archivelink
entry.content:
This issue is not a functional GOS problem but a classic ArchiveLink / OpenText repository mismatch caused by repository or document type changes.

Based on your description, the most likely root causes are:

  1. Content Repository Change

    • You already observed that the content repository in TOA01 was changed.

    • Old documents are still physically stored in the old OpenText repository, but SAP now tries to open them via the new repository, so:

      • Documents no longer open directly

      • SAP forces download/export

      • File names and metadata are missing

  2. Missing or Incorrect MIME / Viewer Mapping

    • When documents open only after export, it usually means:

      • Viewer assignment is broken

      • MIME type is not correctly recognized

    • Check:

      • OAC3 → Document type → “Display in SAP GUI”

      • OAC0 / OAC2 → Viewer assignment for PDF

      • OAER / OAA3 (depending on release)

  3. Document Type Change (Z**PDF → Z**PFR)

    • Even if descriptions look the same, technical settings may differ

    • Compare both document types in OAC3:

      • MIME type

      • Viewer

      • “Original application”

      • Display behavior

  4. Old Repository Not Reachable

    • The error “document archived” strongly indicates:

      • Old OpenText repository is offline / decommissioned

      • RFC destination or HTTP destination no longer exists

    • BASIS must verify:

      • OpenText repository connectivity

      • ArchiveLink RFCs

      • Repository still mounted on OpenText side

entry.title: Re: API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV - Attach PDF document to Supplier Invoice
entry.content: This is a known limitation with the CPI OData adapter, which only supports JSON/ATOM payloads. For binary PDF uploads to API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV, the correct approach is to use the HTTP adapter, fetch the x-csrf-token first, and then POST the raw binary payload with proper headers (Content-Type: application/pdf). This matches how Postman works and avoids CPI payload transformation issues.

entry.title: Re: Added attachments via API to a supplier invoice are not visible
entry.content: Good clarification. In SAP S/4HANA Cloud, supplier invoice attachments via API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV are supported only from release 1811 onward using communication arrangement SAP_COM_0057. Also important: when calling the API, the LinkedSAPObjectKey must be passed without the slash (InvoiceNumber + FiscalYear concatenated), otherwise attachments won’t appear in the UI. Enabling HDM (Harmonized Document Management) and maintaining the URL allowlist are mandatory steps as well.

entry.title: Re: Retention Period of PDF Attachments (on Journal Entri...
entry.content: To add one clarification: In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, attachment retention is driven by the business document lifecycle and legal retention rules, not by storage quota. SAP does not automatically delete PDF attachments (Journal Entries / Supplier Invoices) as long as the underlying business document exists and is not archived or deleted via Data Retention Management (DRM). Storage capacity (GB/TB) is a licensing topic and can be extended, but it does not impact audit retention. Auditors can always retrieve attachments electronically within the retention period—no printing required.

entry.title: Re: How can ı block Storage location
entry.content:
Did you mean you want to block storage location for some users ? 

SPRO > Materials Management > Inventory Management > Authorization Management > Authorization check for storage locations.  Activate the authoriztion check for storage location you want to block

In PFCG, restrict the users who can do transactions in this storage location.

 

If you want to block storage location for all users (do not want to use storage location for any future postings):

1) You can use authorizations solution to remove auth for all users in the storage location

2) Change the name of storage location and add prefix "Do not use" --> This will not block but users will not use

3) Use MM06 to mark deletion flag for all materials of this storage location. Also make     M7-127 message as error in configuring messages. Suggest to move all stocks to other storage locations before doing this.

entry.title: Re: regarding Invoice document attachment -VF03
entry.content:
In VF03, attachments shown under System → Services for Object (GOS) → Attachment List are not created automatically by default.

There are two possible ways attachments appear:

  1. Manual GOS attachment
    A user manually attaches a document (PDF, note, etc.) via GOS.
    In this case, the attachment list is enabled only for those billing documents where a user added an attachment.

  2. Automatic attachment via output (ArchiveLink)
    If invoice output (e.g. SmartForm/Adobe) is configured with ArchiveLink, the PDF is automatically stored in the content repository when the output is generated.
    This requires:

    • ArchiveLink configuration (OAC0 / OAC3)

    • Output type configured to store document

    • Content repository assignment to billing document (BUS2037)

If neither manual GOS attachment nor ArchiveLink output is configured, the Attachment List icon will not be active in VF03.

There is no mandatory setting that forces attachments for all invoices.

entry.title: Re: CDS-View for Attachment in Supplier Invoices
entry.content: In S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, attachment metadata for Supplier Invoices is not exposed via CDS views. Standard approach is to use API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV (e.g. GetAllOriginals / GetAttachmentCount) to retrieve attachment details. CDS views can only be used if attachments are created as Document Info Records (DIR); otherwise, attachment access is API-only by design.

entry.title: Re: App for download attachments invoices in mass
entry.content:
In standard SAP (including S/4HANA Cloud), there is no delivered app that allows mass download of invoice attachments out-of-the-box.

Available options:

  • SAP API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV can be used to programmatically retrieve attachments in bulk (recommended approach).

  • Build a custom app or automation (Fiori / BTP / CPI / ABAP report) that:

    • Reads invoice numbers

    • Fetches attachments via API

    • Downloads them in mass (ZIP or structured folders)

  • For on‑premise systems, customers often use:

    • Custom ABAP reports using ArchiveLink (TOA01 / SOOD / SOFFCONT1)

    • DMS-based extraction if attachments are linked to DIRs

Conclusion:
Mass download of invoice attachments requires custom development or API-based automation; it is not supported by a standard SAP app.

entry.title: Re: Report RSBCS_REORG and KPRO ?
entry.content: “‘Deleted from KPRO’ refers to the physical deletion of SAPoffice document content stored in the Knowledge Provider (KPRO) repositories (e.g. attachments, binary content). ‘Deleted Address References’ indicates cleanup of obsolete SAPoffice recipient/address entries (e.g. user, distribution list references) linked to the deleted documents. Both are standard housekeeping actions performed by RSBCS_REORG to keep SAPoffice and workflow data consistent.”

entry.title: Re: RSBCS_REORG still does not delete anything
entry.content: RSBCS_REORG will not delete SAPoffice documents that are still referenced (e.g. in folders, workflows, or via KPRO). Please check: • Documents are not in private/shared folders (SOOD/SOOS) • No active references in workflows or business objects • Retention time parameters and authorization • Run SOST / workflow cleanup reports first SAP Notes on SAPoffice reorganization also explain these limitations.

entry.title: Re: RSBCS_REORG report spending much time over SOOD table
entry.content:
RSBCS_REORG performance issues on SOOD are usually caused by very large data volume and inefficient access paths chosen by the DB optimizer. Even with good stats and indexes, deleting very small date ranges (e.g. 1 day) can force index usage and lead to slow row-by-row deletes.

Recommendations:
• Run RSBCS_REORG in larger date ranges (weekly/monthly) instead of daily
• Execute during low system load and consider background jobs with smaller packages
• Check if KPRO / content server documents are involved, as this increases runtime
• On some DBs, disabling indexes temporarily or using DB-specific delete optimizations helps
• Ensure related cleanup reports (RSBCS_REORG_DEL, RSSO_DELETE_*) are executed in correct sequence

This behavior is known for SAPoffice tables (SOOD/SOOS/SOC3) with many years of data.

entry.title: Re: Strategic Decision Paths for Managing Hazardous Substances: SAP ECC to SAP S/4HANA Migration

entry.title: Re: Raw material from international vendor to Finished go...
entry.content:
Hi, 

As per understanding your question,

RM from international vendor > sent to External Manufacturer via Plant 1025 (CC1106) > FG received directly at Plant 1800 (CC1100):

  1. Create PO for Raw Material (International Vendor)

ME21N: PO with Plant = 1025, storage location as per process, Incoterms, etc.

  1. Post Import Goods Receipt of Raw Material at Plant 1025

MIGO (GR for PO): Post GR to 1025 (stock available for issue to subcontractor).

  1. Create Subcontracting / External Processing PO for Finished Goods

ME21N: PO to External Manufacturer (Subcontractor)

Item: Finished Good material with Item Category = L (Subcontracting)

Maintain Component list (raw materials/packing if applicable) in PO (or via BOM).

  1. Create Delivery / Issue Components to Subcontractor from Plant 1025

MIGO: Transfer Posting O (Issue components to subcontractor) Stock moves from Plant 1025 to Subcontractor stock (Special stock O)

  1. Subcontractor Manufactures Finished Goods

Physical manufacturing happens at vendor site (no SAP production order needed unless you use advanced integration).

Post Subcontracting Goods Receipt of Finished Goods directly into Plant 1800

  1. MIGO (GR for Subcontracting PO) with Plant = 1800  Receive FG directly into Plant 1800 stock, and system consumes components from vendor stock automatically (based on consumption quantity).

Invoice Verification

  1. MIRO: Post vendor invoice (service/processing charges + any agreed components variance handling).
  2. Stock / Account Verification

Check stock and movements:

MB51 / ME2L, ME23N History, MMBE for stock.

Regards

entry.title: Re: Question: Delivery-cost condition error during Servic...
entry.content:
Delivery cost conditions are primarily designed for logistics processes involving goods receipt, freight, and transportation costs. In material POs, these conditions integrate naturally with GR and invoice verification. However, in service POs, the system processes costs differently because there is no physical delivery or freight component. This mismatch can sometimes trigger errors during Service Entry Sheet (SES) creation if the pricing procedure still expects delivery-related conditions.

Even if the condition is manual and has no records, the system may still treat it as relevant during SES processing if the condition type is flagged as mandatory in the pricing schema, the calculation schema is applied uniformly to both material and service POs without differentiation and the condition category is set in a way that makes it applicable to services, which can cause validation checks during SES posting.

SAP generally expects delivery cost conditions to be excluded from service scenarios, since services do not involve freight or delivery. If the same PO document type and pricing schema are used for both materials and services, the system cannot distinguish automatically. This is why configuration adjustments are often required.

To fix this

  • Use different calculation schemas for material vs. service POs, excluding delivery cost conditions from the service schema.
  • Review the condition type in transaction M/06 and ensure it is not marked as mandatory for service-related schemas.
  • Check schema determination rules (via M/08) to ensure service POs do not inherit delivery cost conditions unnecessarily.
  • Sometimes, conditions behave differently depending on account assignment. Verify if the SES error is linked to account assignment validation.

entry.title: Re: FREIGHT COST (Planned Delivery costs)
entry.content:
Why the issue occurs is because, planned Delivery Costs in SAP are tied to the PO header and linked to a single freight vendor. When you post partial goods receipts, the system distributes the planned delivery costs proportionally. At invoice posting (MIRO), SAP expects the invoicing party to match the freight vendor defined in the PO. If a different freight vendor is used for subsequent deliveries, the system throws the “Invoicing Party is different” error because the PO does not allow multiple freight vendors for planned delivery costs.

Below are the SAP Best Practices for International Procurement

Use Unplanned Delivery Costs
Instead of fixing freight vendor and costs at PO level, post freight invoices as unplanned delivery costs during MIRO. This allows you to enter different freight vendors and amounts per invoice without PO dependency. The costs are distributed to the PO items automatically.

Separate Freight POs (Service POs)
Create a service PO for freight services per shipment. Each freight forwarder is represented as a separate PO with its own vendor. This keeps the material PO clean and allows flexibility in handling multiple freight vendors.

Use Condition Types for Freight (Delivery Costs)
Configure freight condition types as non‑mandatory and allow manual entry at invoice level. This way, you can adjust freight charges per delivery without system errors.

Split Invoices by Vendor
Post material supplier invoices separately from freight supplier invoices. Each freight invoice can be posted against the PO with unplanned delivery costs or against a dedicated freight PO.

entry.title: Re: Raw material from international vendor to Finished go...
entry.content:
Here is a different way to structure the same business requirement in SAP ECC, using an alternative but still standard approach. You can model the flow with stock transfers and cross‑company processes. This gives you more control over valuation and accounting between company codes.

Raw Material Procurement (International Vendor → Plant 1025, CC1106)
ME21N: Create a standard PO for raw materials with plant = 1025.
MIGO: Post GR into plant 1025. Raw materials are now available in CC1106.

2. Transfer Raw Materials to Subcontractor
ME21N: Create a stock transport order (STO) or use subcontracting PO depending on setup.
MIGO: Issue raw materials to subcontractor (movement type 541).
Stock moves into special stock O at subcontractor, still owned by plant 1025.

3. Finished Goods Receipt into Plant 1025 (Optional Step)
If you want to keep the subcontracting cycle consistent, you can first post the finished goods receipt back into plant 1025 (movement type 101 for subcontracting PO). This consumes the raw materials from subcontractor stock and creates FG stock in plant 1025.

4. Cross‑Company Stock Transfer (Plant 1025 → Plant 1800)
ME21N: Create a stock transport order between plant 1025 (CC1106) and plant 1800 (CC1100).
VL10B / VL10D: Create outbound delivery from plant 1025.
VL02N: Post goods issue (movement type 351).
MIGO: Post goods receipt in plant 1800 (movement type 101).

This ensures proper intercompany billing between CC1106 and CC1100 if required.

5. Invoice Verification
MIRO: Post invoice for the subcontractor (processing charges).
Intercompany Billing: If STO is intercompany, create billing document in SD (VF01) and post invoice to CC1100.

This ensures correct financial postings between company codes.

entry.title: Re: MRP-RUN : STR ( stock transfer requisition) cansidred...
entry.content:
Why this happens is because, Planned order in 1003 → converted to STR (PR with doc type for stock transfer). MRP in 1008 sees the requirement element (planned order/STR) regardless of release status. Release strategy in MM controls whether the requisition can be converted into a PO, but it does not block MRP from considering the requirement. Hence, MD04 in 1008 shows the dependent requirement even for STRs that are not yet approved.

Options to handle this

1. Use Release Indicator to Control MRP Relevance
In release strategy configuration SPRO → Materials Management → Purchasing → Purchase Requisition → Release Procedure, you can set the release indicator to determine whether the requisition is “blocked” for further processing. If you configure the release indicator so that unreleased STRs are not relevant for MRP, then only approved STRs will be considered in the supplying plant. This requires customizing the release indicator to affect MRP explosion. This requires careful customizing because unreleased STRs remain in the requesting plant, but are not exploded into dependent requirements in the supplying plant until the release indicator changes to “Released.” In practice, this is achieved by using different release indicators tied to different processing flags (e.g., “blocked for follow‑on processing”).

2. Separate Document Types for STRs
Use a different PR document type for STRs that are subject to release. Configure MRP so that only requisitions with a certain document type (or release status) are considered in the supplying plant. This way, unreleased STRs remain invisible to MRP in 1008.

3. BAdI / User Exit Enhancement
Standard SAP does not automatically exclude unreleased STRs from MRP. You can use enhancement spots such as BAdI MD_PURREQ_RELEASE or exits in MRP run to filter out unreleased STRs. This is a common approach when business requires strict dependency on release approval.

4. Workflow / Process Control
Instead of trying to block MRP, you can control the timing of MRP runs in plant 1008. Run MRP in 1008 only after STRs in 1003 have been approved. This is a process workaround rather than configuration, but it ensures dependent requirements are aligned with approvals.
